Sun of Faith - English: Chapter 11 - Princess Yashodhara is selected
After consulting his ministers, King Shuddhodana
Manual - English: The Buddha enters the city in a carriage. He prophesies to many brahmins who are leaving the city.  On a spacious porch, the Buddha gives a gift item to each of the many Shakya girls. The Buddha gives a finger ring to Yashodhara (grags 'dzin ma).  In a mansion, there is a wedding banquet for taking Yashodhara as his bride.

Sun of Faith - English: decided to introduce all the eligible young noblewomen of the land to the prince,
so that he himself might choose as wife the one he loved best.
Since Siddhartha delighted in giving gifts,
learning exactly who was the object of his heart's desire simply entailed getting a splendid dowry of jewels ready, and observing him closely when he distributed them to the young women.
Once this decision was reached, astrological calendars were consulted.
On the auspicious day so determined, the Bodhisattva mounted the throne of lions rampant set in the middle of a huge square.
The highest peers of the realm crowded round the prince, and in front of him glittered a heap of jewelry sets fashioned with gold and precious stones.
One after another, dressed in their finest apparel and wearing their traditional ornaments, the loveliest and noblest women filed past him.
To each he presented an item of jewelry.
However Yashodhara (Grags 'dzin ma), daughter of the Shakya, Dandapani (Lag na be con) would not stir from her seat.
“Go on, go and receive a tiara from the prince's own hand,” her father urged.
“Why on earth? Don't we already have quite enough trinkets?”
“That has nothing to do with it!” her father exclaimed. “The prince is trying to select a wife for himself.”
“Whether he selects me or not, it is he and no other than he who will be my husband!”
“All the more reason to introduce yourself to him!” Dandapani pointed out.
Yashodhara, whose dazzling beauty would have eclipsed all other women, waited till everyone had filed past before advancing towards the throne.
But the Bodhisattva had given away the very last article of jewelry and had nothing left.
[In desperation] his eyes fell on the ring, set with the royal seal, that he had on, and showed it to Yashodhara.
She glided up the throne steps and herself slipped the ring off the Bodhisattva's finger.
“Now here's a woman who will suit the prince perfectly!” whispered the ministers and the other worthies—
and they rushed away to inform Shuddhodana that his plan had been a success.
The king invited Yashodhara, along with her twenty thousand waiting-women, to become the prince's wife.
